awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Energy Harvesting Systems with Ultra High Energy and Power Densities from Ocean Waves and Currents for Green Energy Generation
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project proposes to develop an energy harvesting system from ocean waves and currents utilizing the high energy density and high strain density achieved by recent advances in the development of ionic nano-composites. With the growing need for clean and renewable energy, this topic is of interest to the energy industry and general public. The massive ocean surface of the world holds enormous potential for green energy.  However, the low energy density and power density of all the current energy harvesting approaches impose severe limitations on utilizing this promising technology for practical applications.  One fundamental issue in current energy harvesting approaches based on solid-state energy harvesting materials is the low electric energy density of these materials, and of devices based on them. This project will address these challenges by utilizing the high energy and power density of polymer nano-composites. The proposed approach has the potential to achieve more than two orders of magnitude improvement in the energy density and power density as compared with the current energy harvesting approaches based on the use of solid state electroactive materials in ocean waves.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be the availability of abundant, low-cost and environmental friendly energy, as the vast ocean surface can provide an uninterrupted supply of energy. This project, if successful, will have implications for grid-scale electricity production. The technology developed can also be deployed to power mobile devices at sea.  The technology could also be adapted to other energy harvesting approaches based on mechanical motion; for example as a way to power handheld electronics or wireless sensors.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Growing concern for environment and supply of fossil fuel has directed research to explore and recover energy from renewable sources. There is abundant ambient energy available in nature, such as solar, ocean wave currents (mechanical), wind, hydro, and thermal energies.  Effectively harvesting the energy from these tremendous resources can help preserve fossil fuels and lead to environmentally friendly energy solutions. Harvesting all these forms of energy has been of great interest worldwide. The rapidly growing market of autonomous electronics and sensor networks and wearable sensors and electronics has called for developing technologies such as energy harvesting to supplement or even replace batteries. 

One fundamental issue in the current energy harvesting approaches based on the solid state energy harvesting materials is the low electric energy density of these materials and devices based on them. The project intended to address the current challenges by utilize the high energy and power density of polymer nano-composites.

 

In this Phase I STTR project, the Company systematically developed and evaluated the mechanical energy harvesting device based on supercapacitor nanocomposite electrodes, which exhibited a large electroactuation (the inverse of mechanical energy harvesting), and thermal energy harvesting, which exploited the capacitance change of these electrodes with temperature.  The energy harvestings are based on the variable capacitor approach. That is, the change of capacitance of the nanoporous electrodes caused by an external stress/strain (for the mechanical energy harvesting) or temperature (for the thermal energy harvesting) change.

In addition, the pyroelectric energy harvesting materials by exploiting the recent advances in the ferroelectric materials with giant ECE are also explored, thus directly addressing the low energy density issue in the traditional pyroelectric materials. Considering the relative mature nature of the pyroelectric energy harvesting research, the pyroelectric energy harvesting developed in this STTR phase I project will have high probability of a quick transition to commercial products valuable to customers for powering the mobile electronic devices and systems and for green energy generation.

 

The compact size (due to high energy density) and high efficiency of the explored technology will directly address the energy needs of autonomous electronics and sensor networks and wearable sensors and electronics, which are rapid growing markets. The broad impacts are related to the new technologies for energy harvesting from renewable sources such as ocean waves, geothermal heat and energy recovery from waste heat, and hence have direct impact on our energy future. The proposed work will greatly advance the thermal energy harvesting technology by providing high-efficient and low-cost products. The transformational pyroelectric energy harvesting technology will create numerous highly paid high-tech manufacturing positions in the US and reduce the US dependence on imported oil, and facilitate the war against global warming.    

 


Last Modified: 03/20/2015
Modified by: Ailan Cheng
